content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; the triage meeting will happen in about 1h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry
  • @WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
Hi @T-compiler/meeting ! Meeting is starting now. (Add :wave: to show you are here.)

So we will start off with ten minutes for

Announcements

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add 32-bit and 64-bit stderr/stdout files for ui tests" compiler-team#365
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Move query implementation outside rustc_middle" compiler-team#388
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Add a NOOP_METHOD_CALL lint for methods which should never be directly called" compiler-team#375
    • "refactor the unsafe checking to work on the THIR" compiler-team#402

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize Seek::stream_position (feature seek_convenience)" rust#70904
    • [T-compiler] "rustc: Stabilize -Zrun-dsymutil as -Csplit-debuginfo" rust#79570
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize unsigned_abs" rust#80959
Also, important announcement: Tomorrow we will be having a planning meeting for our first sprint of 2021
Its in our normal slot for steering meetings: Same time as this meetng, just on Friday: 2021-01-29T10:00:00-05:00
If you are on the compiler team or compiler-contributors, you should have received an email survey related to this. Please take a few minutes to send us the survey results! Thanks :)
(and if you didn't get the survey, reach out to myself or Wesley and we'll see if we can resolve it!)
WG checkins

@WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry:

  • currently in a planning phase for the coming year, see 2021 roadmap topic
  • have some pending RFCs (stream trait, warnings about types that ought not to be live over yield)
  • nikomatsakis is working on an async vision document and interested in getting feedback

@WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli :

  • @Esteban Küber and @oli (soon) have much more time for diagnostics
  • cross-await-borrow-failure explanation: #80614
  • move in method call in loop explanation: #80324
  • [internal] document diagnostics infrastructure: #80046
  • take negative impls into account for "trait item not found" errors: #79790
  • improve attribute spans for diagnostics on attributes: #79509
any other announcements? Its snowing outside!
okay, well if someone wants time at the end, privmsg me
next up, beta-nominations

Beta-nominations

T-compiler

• "Revert 78373 ("dont leak return value after panic in drop")" rust#81257
    • This revert #78373, as per last week's discussion
    • Is being reviewed

I would like assistance figuring out why I'm not seeing the coverage html get updated by my local runs, since I cannot fix the PR without doing that. Also: Will a @bors try run do the full test sutie and thus illustrate the breakage from the broken coverage file?
bors try will run precisely zero tests
That was two questions, sorry. First question: Is there any expert here in the coverage tooling and how those files get generated, what depedencies they have?

simulacrum said:

bors try will run precisely zero tests

So... is there a way to simulate what a bors merge attempt will do, since the PR CI does not do the full suite?

Is there any expert here in the coverage tooling and how those files get generated, what depedencies they have?

I have some knowledge of this so we can take that offline.
Okay, thanks @Wesley Wiser
Maybe I'll follow up with @simulacrum about my second question then
anyway this seems to be backport approved.

• "parser: Collect tokens for values in key-value attributes" rust#81337
    • opened by @Vadim Petrochenkov
    • approved by @Aaron Hill
    • Fixes rust#81208, a P-medium issue where a non-ASCII string in the #[path] attribute raised an ICE
low risk, seems fine to me
yeah beta accepted
(the P-medium gave me pause, but I think we should go ahead with backport.)

libs-impl

  • No beta nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • "rustdoc: Fix visibility of trait and impl items" rust#81288
    • Opened by @Camelid
    • r'ed and approved by Joshua Nelson
    • Fixes part of #81274, where documentation does not show as pub the next() method from Iterator (and other Traits)
(Re:medium, the ice precludes an actionable error)
"precludes?" Not sure I'd use that word here. In any case, the error output includes the relevant problem
which I think is what you are saying: That it includes the relevant info you need to fix the problem, which is why the priority here is relatively low
does that all sound correct?
Ah, now that I remember, the error not being emitted is a dupe. Disregard my aside.
TIL the word "preclude"
Ah okay, so you were using the word "preclude" correctly, I just didn't know what you were referencing.
anyway, re rust#81288
I'm very loquacious when I'm half asleep.
I'm in favor of backporting
This seems, to me, like a fairly large regression
I'm okay with backporting
The last one, seems safe

pnkfelix said:

T-rustdoc

I know nothing about rustdoc itself but if we do backport, then it seems we can prevent the regression from hitting stable which seems good to me.
okay backport approved.

Stable-nominations

T-compiler

• "Make hitting the recursion limit in projection non-fatal" rust#81055
    • opened by @Matthew Jasper
    • assigned to @nikomatsakis not yet approved
    • Fixes rust#80953, a regression discovered the crater run for 1.50 that impacted
    • approved for beta backport, stable backport was left open to discussion last week
...I've been reading this just now...
I was planning to r+
I would like to talk a bit more to @Matthew Jasper about what they see as the long term plans here
At this point the release will happen in .. two weeks?
we already approved beta backport
I propose we decline to stable backport
since this hasn't even hit nightly yt
I agree with that
If we don't get this into the current beta

nikomatsakis said:

I would like to talk a bit more to Matthew Jasper about what they see as the long term plans here

Chalk :wink:
then we can renominate for stable backport again
okay?
I r+'d with p=1
declining for stable backport

libs-impl

  • No stable nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • "Restore .editorconfig" rust#81260
    - opened by vn971
    - Looks like the .editorconfig (a suggest file for text editors on how to handle code) was unintentionally removed.
    - @simulacrum inclined to merge if no concerns, what's the general opinion on adding it back?
this is not getting re-added
it's a fresh addition
what is the "unintentionally removed" comment about then?
Is that a mistake in the comments that was transcribed into agenda?
I've probably misunderstood the first part of the issue : "It was previously removed in commit acdf83f inside pull request #45002..."
it's because it was in clippy and subtrees produce odd git artifacts
okay
yes, the agenda was transcribed from misleading comments in the beginning I suspect
I think it was miri actually, and I removed it when I merged miri into rustc back when it became the const evaluator
How big a deal is this?
worthy of an MCP?
IMO it probably doesn't affect anyone who would be the audience for MCP
i.e., people already contributing surely have editors configured
seems really unproblematic
"just merge" imo
I think we should just merge if there's no objection
I'm mildly in favor of merging. For editors that are .editorconfig aware, this can make the experience slightly nicer but not a big deal either way.
okay, I guess we could just do it, as long as its settings are consistent with our style guidelines + tidy expectations
so we just merge and hope for best? It is indeed absurdly low risk.
agreed
ok, will follow up
okay,thanks @simulacrum !

libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 64 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 39 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 5 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 3 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 40 P-high, 89 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • "File implementation on Windows has unsound methods" rust#81357
    • an unsoundness on how Rust handles the Windows I/O API, should be probably marked as critical. we don't have a MVCE from a Windows user, but possibly it's been there since long time.
    • libs meeting report by @Ashley Mannix: seems the consensus is ack one of the options suggested by the issue reporter (call GetOverlappedResult and if it returns error, call abort())
I'm assuming the libs team is on top of this
but no one is assigned
That's something I can pick up.
@Mara ^ does libs team typically assign owners for critical issues ?
okay thanks @Arlie Davis
I work with John Starks, who filed that issue.
we should ping the windows group perhaps

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
but maybe not necessary if we have a plan of action

nikomatsakis said:

we should ping the windows group perhaps

Arlie is on that group FYI

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Cross-compiling Rust to s390x yields a faulty toolchain" rust#80810
    • Opened by Jakob-Naucke
    • discussed last week, @pnkfelix self-assigned
    • seems to affect specifically s390x or to be related to endianess
    • Issue not yet completely clear, could be checked against PR #80732 (not ready for merge yet)
    • @cuviper comments that this issue could also be unrelated to endianess
I haven't had time to look at this. I'm hoping I'll have time tomorrow, but I would love to hand it off
I'll keep it self-assigned but if anyone wants it, ping me (and optionally, go ahead and steal it as well)

• "regression 1.50: Borrow checker reports function param as not living long enough" rust#80949
    • opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • Smallest MCVE found points to PR #78373
    • @Matthew Jasper comments that pr #78373 caused MIR to have one fewer basic block which reduced borrowck precision
    • @Matthew Jasper added additional details
    • @pnkfelix is working on PR rust#81257 to revert rust#78373 and fix this issue
yep, we just talked about this in beta backports; I'm going to follow up with @Wesley Wiser about the coverage tool stuff that is blocking me landing the PR

• "regression 1.50: deny after forbid breaks build" rust#80988
    • Opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • Assigned to @pnkfelix
    • possibly related to issue #77713
    • @simulacrum points to PR #78864 and figures out the root cause
    • discussed in the T-lang meeting, the decision would be to close this
    • @pnkfelix comments that the specific issue discussed in the RFC is probably best dealt in issue #81218
    • entered in final-comment-period as disposition closed
hmm i thought FCP was cancelled here
This is canceled as of tuesday, yeah
okay
yeah I'm going to fix this too
I think @pnkfelix you said you'd prepare a revert? that's why it is assigned to you
yes I'm just pointing out the agenda description is misleading
(not preparing revert for this one, I don't think. Well, maybe it will come to that.)
ah, future incompat, ok
(Ideally it will be a future-incompat warning. But you're right, I might do revert for very-short-term.)
feel free to ping with questions
Thanks
Given the timeline, a revert might well be in order
we'll see.

pnkfelix said:

yes I'm just pointing out the agenda description is misleading

as an aside, who can I talk to in case of doubts with figuring out the context on a issue for the agenda? Can I ping simulacrum or ... ?

pnkfelix said:

Given the timeline, a revert might well be in order

so
@apiraino that is a good question
I think the reason I did not suggest a revert is
the original work was already fixing a regression
(iirc)
yeah, we'd need to revert and re-apply the original fix or so
Do you want me to take on the future incompat warning?
I actually could probably do that today, @pnkfelix
given that I'm going to be in a 6hour meeting (don't ask) and I expect that at least some of that time I will be spacing out :P
@apiraino I think if you are unsure about something, ping me and/or @simulacrum and/or @Wesley Wiser on the disucssion thread in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization
yeah that seems right to me
@nikomatsakis how about you and I follow up today about that?
Sounds good

• "beta regression: forbid(warnings) interacts poorly with common derives." rust#81218
    - Spawned from above issue rust#80988 (discussed last week) to address specifically forbid and derive interacting surprisingly
    - @simulacrum added some comments after last week's discussion
this is covered by the same bug we were just discussing
yep
Whatever we (@nikomatsakis and/or I) do to resolve it will cover it.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • "Breaking change in wasm32-unknown-unknown's ABI on nightly" rust#81386
    - opened by @Alex Crichton
    - he points to PR rust#80594 (cc: @Vadim Petrochenkov)
    - @bjorn3 has worked on PR rust#81388 for a possible fix, needs a review
So @bjorn3 desparately needs a reviewer here
and alex crichton made it very clear that they are not in a position to be the reviewer
well, we can also revert in the meantime? right?
I can plausibly review

pnkfelix said:

Mara ^ does libs team typically assign owners for critical issues ?

libs doesn't, as the stable public api itself (the interface i mean, as opposed to the implementation) usually doesn't have critical issues. but yes, a libs-impl team will have to start doing this. I'll make sure that happens. thanks for the reminder.
I'm familiar with this code
Though reverting may also make sense
if there's an urgent problem IMO we should immediately land a revert rather than waiting on review and some presumably back and forth
did the regression bug identify a PR to reveert?
I'm skimming the thread and I agree about reverting
yes https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/80594
I assume #80594 is what needs to be reverted?
okay, was injected by PR #80594
I'm not sure if the whole PR needs reverting or just one commit
given that its a refactoring PR, i'd say revert the whole thing if you can
well
I don't know what I think
Do whatever's easiest: If you don't know the code, then reverting the whole PR may be easiest.
In #80594 I made a small change based on a invariant I thought would hold, but that invariant doesn't. The fix PR reverts just this change.
Ah
hm
I am pretty sure that the rest of the changes either don't effect the ABI at all or only the rust ABI (this for a 0.5% perf win).
Okay well we need someone to own either composing a new revert or reviewing PR #81388 as a targetted revert
@nikomatsakis you willing to do that? I'd rather have you on that task than the future-incompat thing.
I guess - it maybe makes sense for @nikomatsakis to review the original PR just in case as well
The invariant I thought would hold is that an layout.abi of Abi::ByRef would never result in PassMode::Direct, but only PassMode::Cast or PassMode::Indirect.
I want to move along

Performance logs

2020-01-26 Triage full logs

This week continues a trend of relatively large rollups, which often contain perf-sensitive PRs. We need to get better at marking PRs as rollup=never or otherwise not including them, but it is unclear how precisely to go about doing so. The tooling for testing individual PRs merged in rollups should also be improved to work better in the next few days, though.

Other than that, this week saw several regressions, most of which were not easily explained. We are seeking feedback from PR authors and reviewers on whether the results are expected and if anything can be done.

Triage done by @rylevick and @simulacrum.

5 Regressions, 2 Improvements, 1 Mixed;
3 of them in rollups

pnkfelix said:

nikomatsakis you willing to do that? I'd rather have you on that task than the future-incompat thing.

I can do that

Regressions

Deprecate-in-future the constants superceded by RFC 2700 #80958

  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 2.4% on incr-patched: Job builds of regex-check)
  • Unsure why this might be causing performance regressions as this change does not touch much code and only produces lint warnings when the user opts into them.
  • The author of the PR was asked why this might be the case, and a nag noted.

Rollup of 11 pull requests #81240

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 2.0% on full builds of keccak-check)
  • Revert kicked off here to test a possible culprit in #81178.

Generate metadata by iterating on DefId instead of traversing the HIR tree 1/N #80919

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.0% on incr-patched: println builds of style-servo-check)
  • Contact the PR author to see why the perf regressions were not discussed in the initial PR (even though perf runs were done). Waiting on their response.

Rollup of 14 pull requests #81355

  • Very large regression in instruction counts (up to 12.6% on full builds of deeply-nested-async-debug)

Prevent query cycles in the MIR inliner #68828

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 2.1% on full builds of keccak-check)
  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.8% on full builds of ctfe-stress-4-check)
  • Nag filed
(note that @oli did post a response on #80919)

Improvements

  • Visit only terminators when removing unneeded drops #81122
  • Rollup of 15 pull requests #81304

Mixed

  • mark raw_vec::ptr with inline #79113

Nags requiring follow up

  • Deprecate in future regression #80958
  • Waiting on response to inquiry.
  • Regression in prevent query cycles in the MIR inliner - expected? #68828
I'm looking into #68828, but it may take me a bit, I'm swamped next week
likewise, @bstrie posted response in #80958
and @oli will hopefully look into #68828 , but maybe that investigation could be delegated?
anyway, some regressions, somewhat troubling, but overall I think people are responding to nag requests, so the performance review system is itself hopefully working ...

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "split dwarf doesn't work with crate dependencies" rust#81024
    • Mentioning @davidtwco message on Zulip

pnkfelix said:

anyway, some regressions, somewhat troubling, but overall I think people are responding to nag requests, so the performance review system is itself hopefully working ...

yeah I would look to call out a reminder to folks to mark things as rollup=never somewhat more eagerly

pnkfelix said:

  • "split dwarf doesn't work with crate dependencies" rust#81024
    • Mentioning davidtwco message on Zulip

I'm looking for feedback on some proposed solutions that I have for this issue, rust#81024 has the details.

simulacrum said:

pnkfelix said:

anyway, some regressions, somewhat troubling, but overall I think people are responding to nag requests, so the performance review system is itself hopefully working ...

yeah I would look to call out a reminder to folks to mark things as rollup=never somewhat more eagerly

how expensive are perf runs? Could we e.g. do a perf run proactively, and have a bot add rollup=never for cases where the perf isn't approximately zero cost?
perf runs are cheap, that also works
It won't cover all cases, but it seems like it might cover a lot
Off-line, I'd like to understand what it would take to improve perf test coverage for Windows.
back to #81024
@davidtwco has a big writeup, I'm not sure we can do it justice in the time we have here
who should own this topic?

pnkfelix said:

who should own this topic?

what is "this topic" referring to specifically?
I think debuginfo and the debugging experience overall is important. We've lost our main experts in the space over time
Hm
but it seems obvious it needs its own WG
anyway
I'm inclined to agree with that, but I think for purposes of this meeting best we can do is to encourage folks to reach out to you + @Wesley Wiser --
I think all I can do for right now is give you all a heads up: If you have time, please look over issue #81024. @davidtwco is looking for input from the team
I will try to look at it
I do think we should be looking for more effective ways to recruit interested people and help bring them up into that role
we may have to allocate a steering meeting to the topic or something
I know a few things from reading the DWARF specification as part of getting basic debuginfo support for cg_clif, but I am far from an expert.
I promised someone who priv msg'ed me that we'd get to teh end of the agenda today

libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • "RFC: Checking conditional compilation at compile time" rfcs#3013
    • review by by @Wesley Wiser
    • RFC author implemented new suggestions
I think my last suggestion is still outstanding
Which one? I thought I responded to most everything.
I don't think this is something that can really be fixed by this RFC, it's just something that should be noted.
But I may have missed you adding it
Ah, right. Specifically, the case of a #[cfg] in a nested module not being caught?
Oh, I'm now realizing I may not have been clear enough. I wanted to see it added to the drawbacks section and to make sure that this was something you were aware of.
Yeah
(We can take this offline to not hold up the meeting)
okay so that's a detail, not a dealbreaker for the RFC
I'll get that added to the drawbacks section.
Overall, I think it's a great improvement over the status quo so I plan to start an fcp merge soon
@Wesley Wiser it sounds like you've already invested time ... yes, great
exactly what I was hoping you'd say
Okay then! Four minutes to spare!
Surely that's enough time for me to go carry out things I promised above
But in all seriousness: Great meeting folks. Oh
here's a question
who's planning on coming to steering meeting tomorrow? Hands up on this comment if so
okay. I was a little concerned when the number of hands stalled at five or so, This is better. But longer term, we may want to revise the meeting schedule
I worry we're missing out on input from important stakeholders. I don't know how to fix that yet.
Thanks for attending this meeting everyone! Stay safe, stay healthy, stay happy!

Next meeting agenda draft is available here:
https://hackmd.io/NXkmORWLSk-WKy4lv8p1YA?view

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino (Joshua is taking some time off)
  • @wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser
seems like https://github.com/rust-lang/team/pull/525 could have been in the announcements section of the meeting :)
oh very good point, thanks :) I'll note it down for the next time
